question: Forgive me... How long has this man been here?
answer: Three quarters of an hour.

question: Mmmm. Hodges, Pierce come closer. Mr. Hill, take hold of the rope please. It's a machine accident. I expect you'll be seeing a good deal of this. Abominable things these machines. One can't reason with them.
answer: What a mess.

question: No... I don't think so.
answer: Are you the proprietor?

question: And who might you be, sir?
answer: Just one of the curious. I'd like to see it.

question: I don't think so. No sir, we're closed.
answer: I'd pay handsomely for a private showing. Are you the proprietor?

question: Handsomely?... Who sent you?
answer: Pardon me?

question: So you'll bring him to me, tomorrow, 10:00 a.m.? Mr...?
answer: Bytes. Mr. Bytes. He'll be there.

question: I'll send a cab. Here is my card.
answer: Now we got a deal... We understand each other... guv. We understand each other completely. Don't just stand there. Help him up.

question: I'll be in my rooms, Mothershead. I'm not to be disturbed. Come with me, please. My name is Frederick Treves... I am a surgeon here at the London Hospital, and I lecture in anatomy at the Medical College... I would very much like to examine you. Would that be all right? Ah... yes. Um, first I would like to ask you a few questions, would that be all right? Good. Now, let's see. Your Owner... um, the man who... who looks after you tells me that you are English and your name is John Merrick. Is that correct? Do you know where you were born? Where you come from? I tell you what, I'll ask you a question, and you shake your head like this for "no" and nod like this for "yes", alright? Do you understand? Are you in any pain? Um, no. Just nod your head like this for "yes" and shake it like this for "no". Now, are you in any pain? Are your parents still alive? Do you understand? Are they dead? Your father... your mother?
answer: Freddie, what you doing for... I say do open a window in here or... Oh, I'm dreadfully sorry, I had no idea that... I say! Good Lord, Freddie! What have you got in there?

question: You'll know presently. At the meeting of the society. But until then, I beg of you Fox, keep it to yourself.
answer: Certainly, if you insist. You must have quite a find there.

question: I don't know what I've got.
answer: Nothing of any importance, eh?

question: I'll tell you this much, Fox, it's beyond anything you or I have ever dealt with. Keep it to yourself, please. Come sit down. Sit... down. I think I'll examine you now. I'll save the questions for later... Will you take off your hat now, please? Don't be frightened, I simply want to look at you. Do you understand? That's right, don't be frightened. Don't be frightened. Are you ready? Go ahead. He is English, he is twenty-one years of age and his name is John Merrick. Gentlemen, in the course of my profession I have come upon lamentable deformities of the face due to injury or disease, as well as mutilations and contortions of the body, depending upon like causes; but, at no time have I met with such a dreaded or perverted version of a human being as this man. I wish to draw your attention to the insidious conditions affecting this patient. Note, if you will, the extreme enlargement of the skull... and upper limb, which is totally useless. The alarming curvature of the spine... Turn him, please... the looseness of the skin, and the varying fibrous tumors that cover 90% of the body. ...And there is every indication that these afflictions have been in existence, and have progressed rapidly, since birth. The Patient also suffers from chronic bronchitis. As an interesting side-note, in spite of the afore-mentioned anomalies, the patient's genitals remain entirely intact and unaffected. So then, gentlemen, owing to this series of deformities Hmm? Hmm? It's been a long day for everyone. Oh, yes, you'll need a cab... Stay. Come with me.
answer: You never mentioned his mental state.

question: He's imbecile, no doubt from birth. He speaks, but... it's all gibberish. No, the man's a homeless idiot... I pray God he's an idiot.
answer: I pity the poor cab driver, myself.

question: I'll get my bag.
answer: What did you do to him? He's been like this all night!

question: What do you mean?
answer: He was fine when he left here, and now look at him.

question: I intend to. What happened?
answer: He fell. He falls.

question: He must have taken quite a fall.
answer: He's a clumsy git. Never watches where he is going.

question: Why is he sitting up like this? He needs rest.
answer: That's the way he sleeps. If he lays down, he'll die. Head's too heavy.

question: This man belongs in hospital.
answer: Can't you fix him up here? ...He's my livelihood. Listen.

question: You listen, you're not going to have much of a livelihood if this man dies. He's got the rale, he's very weak, and I don't know how much damage has been done by his "fall". Now stop wasting time and fetch a cab.
answer: I really appreciate this, guv. You know, there's lot of things that I can do for you. I move in the proper circles, for this type of thing... (motioning toward the I like doing business with you. You and I understand each other, completely. I know I can trust you. Can't I?

question: I don't know if you will understand this, but you will never go back to that man again. You're safe now. No one will ever harm you. Do you understand? It's for a patient.
answer: Mr. Treves, come over here a moment, won't you? Good morning, Treves.

question: Good morning, sir.
answer: You've acquired a taste for this?

question: It's quite nutritious, sir.
answer: Don't be mad. This muck can kill you. Take this up, to to the man in the isolation ward when you have a moment, won't you?

question: Don't be frightened. He won't hurt you.
answer: Indeed! A hospital is no place for secrecy, Mr. Treves. Doctors spiriting hooded figures about are liable to cause comment. Why wasn't this patient properly admitted, and why is he in isolation? Is he contagious?

question: No sir, he's got bronchitis and he's been badly beaten.
answer: Why isn't he in the General Ward, then?

question: Well sir, he's quite seriously deformed, and I fear the other patients would find him... rather shocking.
answer: Deformed? Is that it. Then am I to assume that he is ultimately incurable?

question: Yes sir.
answer: What are your plans then, Treves... You are aware that the London does not accept incurables. The rules are quite clear on that point.

question: Yes, I'm well aware of that. But this case is quite exceptional.
answer: Oh, is he a friend of yours?

question: No, more of an acquaintance.
answer: I certainly sympathize with your problem, Treves... Why don't you try the British Home, or the Royal Hospital for perhaps they would have a place for him.

question: Yes sir, I'll look into that. Would you like to meet him sir? Excuse me, sir.
answer: The Elephant Man?

question: Ah, Mothershead. How are you feeling today?
answer: Fine.

question: Good. Excellent. Now then, Mrs. Mothershead, I want you to come into this room with me. Inside there is a man with a rather... unfortunate appearance.
answer: I've heard.

question: Yes... Well, I want you to clear up a little mess, a breakfast tray was spilt. And bring up another breakfast. When you've done that, you and I shall give the man a bath. But, Mothershead, I'm counting on your many years of experience to get you through this, Above all, do not scream, do not cry out, or in any way show this man that you are frightened of him...
answer: Sir, you don't have to worry about me. I'm not the sort to cry out. Shall we go in?

question: The disease is shocking. I wonder how far it can go before it...
answer: Sit still. Don't wiggle about like a pup. I won't stand for any foolishness.

question: It's pretty certain that if he had the disease as a child, he was abandoned. But in that case, he'd have to have had care. The very fact that he's alive bears that out... But, where?
answer: The workhouse.

question: Mr. Merrick? ....Good morning... John. I've brought your breakfast. What are you doing down there? Come up John, come up on the bed. The cold floor is bad for you. I won't hurt you, come on now... You must eat. We must keep your strength... ...What on earth is the matter with you? Now please, John, you must do as I say. Come up from there.
answer: Good morning, Mr. Treves. It'll be his bath-time soon. Has he eaten?

question: Not quite yet, Mrs. Mothershead. There seems to be some difficulty this morning.
answer: Won't come out, eh?

question: No, he's very upset about something.
answer: Just being obstinate, sir. I'll handle it. Alright, my son, none of this fuss. Come up from there, this instant.

question: No! Don't pull at him like that. We don't want to frighten him more than he already is.
answer: Honestly, sir, you must be very firm with this sort. Otherwise they'd lay about on the floor gibbering all day long. All he understands is a good smack.

question: He's had his share of "smacks", Mothershead. I expect that's what drives him under the bed. We must use patience and understanding with this man.
answer: Perhaps you've got the time for that, Mr. Treves, I certainly don't. I've got an entire hospital to look after, and you have your real patients. Don't waste your time with him sir, it's like talking to a wall. I don't mean to be harsh, but truthfully what can you do for him? I'll be back later for his bath. And Mr. Carr Gomm would like to see you when you have a moment. Good day sir.

question: What good am I to you...? ...What is my purpose? ...It's so important that I understand you. I want to help you, I want to be your doctor... but I can't help you unless you help me, unless I know what you are feeling. I believe there's something back there, there's something you want to say, but I've got to understand you. Do you understand me? No! You are going to talk to me! We are going to show them! We're going to show them that you're not a wall. We are going to talk! Do you understand? Nod your head if you understand me! You do understand me! You understand. Now you're going to say it. I've got to hear how you say things. Now, very slowly, say "yes." "Yes."
answer: Yyyy... Yyye... yyyess.

question: Yes John!
answer: ...Yyes

question: Yyyess.
answer: Yyess.

question: That's much better. I could understand that "yes".
answer: Yes!

question: Very good! Oh yes! Now listen. I'm going to say some things to you and I want you to repeat them... um... I want you to say them back to me. Do you understand? I'm going to say some things to you and I want you to say them back to me. Do you understand?
answer: Yes.

question: Excellent! Now, say... "Hello"
answer: Hello...

question: My name is...
answer: My... name is...

question: John Merrick.
answer: John... Merrick

question: Say "Merrick".
answer: Merrick...

question: Say "Mmmerrick."
answer: Mmmerrick.

question: Say "Mmmerrick."
answer: Mmmerrick.

question: Well, that's alright. I understand you. Now, say the whole thing again, Hello ...
answer: Hello... my name is... John Merrick.

question: I'm sure that if Mr. Merrick made a good impression on the hospital committee they'd see that he's the exception to their rule. Now I'm not expecting miracles. I'm not saying he'll be able to read or write, but I do think that I can get him to speak for himself. I'm going to arrange things with Carr Gomm right now. That was very good, John, very good. That's all for today. We shall do some more tomorrow. Mothershead? I'll see you soon.
answer: Ah, Treves... Have you contacted the British Home and the Royal Hospital?

question: Ah, no sir. I had planned to see them in the morning.
answer: Good! How is the patient?

question: He's doing very well. In fact that's why I came to see you. I think that if I were to present Mr. Merrick to the hospital committee, then they would have a chance to see for themselves not only the extraordinary nature of the disease, but of the man as well. If the committee had a chance to speak with him, hear him say a few words for himself, I'm sure they would see him as a patient, rather than as a violation of the rules.
answer: A few words? I thought he was imbecile?

question: Well sir, perhaps I should explain...
answer: I really don't think that's necessary Treves. I'm quite sure the committee will be able to make an equitable decision on the merits of the case, such as they are.

question: I don't agree. No one can make a reasonable decision about this man's future without at least meeting him. No doctor would presume to diagnose a patient he had never met.
answer: No, Treves, it's out of the question. Now if it was up to me, I'd say "Certainly, let's meet the fellow, by all means," I'm sorry, I simply can't speak for the other members of the committee.

question: Then will you meet him, as a representative of the committee.
answer: Mr. Treves, it's out of the question. I want to hear as soon as possible what the other hospitals can do. I'm sorry.

question: I want my man back.
answer: Just a moment, how did you get in here?

question: Never mind that, I want my man!
answer: He's still very sick. Please come downstairs with me. I'll explain the situation.

question: DON'T... Don't muck me about. You've had plenty of time to fix him up, and he's leaving with me, NOW. Do you understand me? Now, Mr. Treves. We had a bargain!
answer: You misunderstood. This man suffered a severe fall, if you take my meaning. He's my patient now and I must do what...

question: Pull the other one, why don't you! We made a deal!
answer: I know what you've done to him and he's never going back to that.

question: He's a freak! That's how they live. We're partners, him and I, business partners. You're willfully deprivin' me of my livlihood!
answer: All you do is profit from another man's misery!

question: You think you're better 'n me? YOU wanted the freak to show all your doctor chums and make a name for yourself, you guv. So I gave him to you. On trust, in the name of science! And now I want him back.
answer: You don't own this man!

question: I want him back!
answer: So you can beat him? So you can starve him? A dog in the street would fare better with you!

question: Singularly unpleasant chap... uh... I don't suppose there would be any harm in my meeting your... patient, Mr. Treves.
answer: Thank you very much Sir. Shall we say in a few days then?

question: Shall we say two o'clock tomorrow afternoon?
answer: Wh... whatever is most convenient for you, sir.

question: Two o'clock then... you know Treves... It seems this acquaintance of yours has become rather more than just an acquaintance.
answer: ...Yes, Sir. Two o'clock?

question: Freddie? Freddie?... Freddie, don't look so discouraged.
answer: I shouldn't be. We made great progress today. I taught him to repeat a few basic phrases. He did rather well, too, but I had to lead him every step of the way. Though frankly, at times I was unsure of who was leading whom.

question: What do you mean?
answer: Well, I wasn't sure whether he was parroting me because that's all he was capable of, or whether he sensed that that's all I wanted to hear, and he was trying to please me.

question: But I thought you said that he was rather... simple?
answer: He is. I mean, I've always thought he was. I think he must be. Is he simple? Or is that just something I've wished upon him to make things simpler for myself?

question: Frederick, why are you so interested in this particular case?
answer: I don't know. I can't explain it. If this is an intelligent man, trapped in the body of a monster, then I'm under a moral obligation to help free that mind, free that spirit as best I can, to help him live as full and content a life as possible. But! If he's an imbecile, who's body I can't treat and who's mind I can't touch, well, then my obligation is discharged. They can put him where they will; he won't be bothered, I won't be bothered, and everyone's conscience can remain free and untroubled. And that is my dilemma... what is in his mind?

question: Perhaps you're just polishing a stone, endowing this Elephant Man with qualities he doesn't possess?
answer: And what qualities are those? Intelligence or stupidity?

question: I'm sure I don't know, Freddie.
answer: I'm sorry... I don't know either. I just don't know.

question: Well, these things take time.
answer: I've only got until two o'clock tomorrow afternoon, when Carr Gomm meets him. Somehow, between now and then I've got to make John Merrick at least seem like an intelligent man... Why am I fooling myself? Nothing short of John delivering the Sermon on the Mount is going to sway Carr Gomm...

question: The Lord is my shepherd, I shall not want, he maketh me to lie down in green pastures; He leadeth me beside still waters. He restoreth my soul
answer: Righteousness...

question: Righteousness for his namesake.
answer: Very good, very good. Now, when your visitor comes today I want you to say it exactly the way you said it just now. I will introduce him to you and you will say the words you've learned. If you have any trouble with any of the words, I'll help you. I'm sure you'll be just fine. If you do as well for him as you've done for me these last two days, then I'm sure our visitor will be very pleased. Now, let's go through the whole thing again, shall we? I will say "May I introduce you to Mr. Carr Gomm." And you will say...

question: It's only a physical problem. He has trouble with certain sounds because of the constrictive deformity of the mouth. But he can talk, and has a great eagerness to make contact with people who will let him. So if you have any difficulty understanding what he is saying, just tell me and I'll make it clear.
answer: Speaking is one thing, Treves, but can the man comprehend?

question: ...As I said, it's only a physical problem... but I do feel that Mr. Merrick is very flattered that you're taking the time and trouble to meet him, and he's most anxious to make a good impression, so he might seem rather nervous.
answer: He needn't. I have no desire to cause him any discomfort. Did you make those inquiries we spoke about?

question: Yes, I spoke to both the British Home and Royal Hospital for Incurables. I'm afraid that they weren't very encouraging, but they said they'd bring it up at their next committee meeting, so we should have their answers shortly.
answer: Fine, fine. You know, your dedication to this patient is an inspiring thing, Treves. But you must remember that this is a hospital, and there are many patients here. Patients who can be made well, and you owe them your first consideration. Just don't become so obsessed, old man, that you begin to neglect them.

question: Hello... my name is John Merrick. I am very pleased to meet you.
answer: I'm very... pleased to meet you. How are you feeling today?

question: I feel much better. Thank you for asking. And you?
answer: I'm feeling very fit, thank you. How is your bronchitis?

question: I feel much better. Thank you.
answer: Are you comfortable here?

question: But the variety of food here is very pleasing... I commend you.
answer: I understand that you were beaten? No, I meant in your former situation.

question: I'm feeling much better now...
answer: Tell me, how do you like Mr. Treves? As a teacher?

question: ...I... everyone has been very kind to me.
answer: Of course. How long did you and Mr. Treves prepare for this interview?

question: ...everyone has been very kind.
answer: Yes, of course... Well, it's been a pleasure meeting you, Mr. Merrick. Good day.

question: I hope we can talk together again sometime. Good day.
answer: I'll be right back.

question: I want to see you in my office as soon as you're through up here. We've a good deal to discuss.
answer: Of course, sir. Thank you, thank you very much.

question: Treves. Well done.
answer: Not me, sir. Mr. Merrick. He succeeded in spite of my shortsightedness.

question: Why did you let me go on like that, teaching you what you already knew? Why didn't you tell me you could read?
answer: You did not ask me.

question: I never thought to ask. How can you ever forgive me?
answer: Oh, no do not say that. You have been so kind to me. I was afraid to say too much. People always want me to be quiet. You wanted me to speak, but I was afraid. Forgive me.

question: We do have a lot to talk about, don't we?
answer: Can you imagine what his life has been like?

question: Yes, I think I can.
answer: No you can't. You can't begin to know, no one can. You are quite right, Treves, this is an exceptional case. And I quite agree that the committee should see Mr. Merrick.

question: I could easily arrange...
answer: No, not that way. Broadneck and the others don't like to deal with patients directly. It makes them queasy... Do you have any photographs of Mr. Merrick?

question: Well, yes.
answer: Excellent. We shall present them, along with the other particulars of the case to the committee. I want them to see, exactly, how horribly his body has been affected. You and I shall vouch for his inner qualities.

question: Do you think they'll go along with us?
answer: Of course they will. They're reasonable men.

question: I hear you have some trouble sleepin'... Head's too heavy, eh? And I heard a nasty rumor about you; I heard you can talk but you can't, can you... can you... can you?...
answer: Noooo!

question: No... No you can't! One word about me out of that stinking cakehole... Just ONE word, and you'll have no trouble at sleepin'... no trouble at all. You understand me? Do you!!
answer: Yyyesss.

question: Gentlemen, may I make a suggestion. There are two small rooms off Bedstead Square that are no longer in use and would be admirably suited to Mr. Merrick's needs. I also propose to write a letter to The Times, appealing to their readers for assistance. Knowing the generosity of the British public, I feel we would have little trouble in raising the funds for his maintenance. Indeed, this hospital's rules do preclude the admission of incurables, but if ever there was an exception to the rule, it is this patient. So therefore, I propose, if Mr. Treves is finished, that we put it to a vote. All those in favor of keeping Mr. Merrick here?
answer: One moment, as far as I'm concerned this creature has no business being in our hospital. I think Mr. Carr Gomm's letter would be an excellent idea, and when you appeal for funds, I think you should appeal for a more appropriate place for him as well. I agree the British public is generous, and I'm sure that somewhere the creature will find a happy and permanent home, but not here.

question: I see. All, then, that move we keep Mr. Merrick here? All those opposed? I see.
answer: Well then. In the meantime, of course, he needn't be turned out. He may stay in the rooms off Bedstead Square until such time as more suitable arrangements can be made, thus freeing the Isolation Ward for more deserving patients. Well then, Mr. Chairman, if there is nothing further to discuss, I move that we adjourn this meeting and all go bout our normal business.

question: "A silent shaft of stone on a deserted promontory, the lonely Eddystone is a beacon of aid and comfort to mariners of all nations."
answer: Good evening. How are you feeling?

question: Good evening. Very well, thank you. And you?
answer: Very well, thank you. I have something for you, John. I'm sure you'll enjoy it, it's very popular.

question: Thank you... so much... oh it's beautiful!
answer: I came to tell you that I'll be here early tomorrow morning. We're moving you to your permanent home. I'm sure you'll be very happy there, John. So get a good night's rest, there'll be new people to meet tomorrow. Good night.

question: Workhouse!
answer: This is your new home, John.

question: This... is my new home?
answer: Yes.

question: The hospital?
answer: Of course! What did you think?

question: How long will I stay here?
answer: I promise you. You will never see the inside of that horrible place again. You will never, ever go back to the workhouse... or that man. It's a splendid room, don't you think?

question: Has the response picked up?
answer: Frankly, Treves, it's not what I'd expected. A few small cheques. Well- wishers. Don't worry, these things undoubtedly take time.

question: But he's so afraid he's going to be carted off. I've promised him that won't happen.
answer: Well... I'll let you know if there's something in the afternoon post.

question: Ugly or not, you're going to help me. Feeling better now, Mr. Merrick?
answer: Yes.

question: You look very nice in your new clothes.
answer: Thank you very much.

question: Well, if there is nothing more, I suppose we'll be leaving you now.
answer: No, nothing.

question: Yes, we do have a lot of room. But you should see the place on weekends, when I see patients here. Sometimes there are so many, we have to set them down wherever we can. In fact, Mrs. Treves sometimes says that the only room she can call her own is the bedroom.
answer: Well, it's a lovely bedroom. What do you call that thing above the bed?

question: That's a canopy, John.
answer: Ohhh...

question: How is your tea, John?
answer: It's very good. I'm enjoying my visit with you very much. It's so very kind of you to have me as a guest in your home. I'm sorry I made a spectacle of myself.

question: Not at all, John.
answer: I love the way you've arranged your pictures on the mantlepiece. Is that the way it's done in most houses?

question: Oh yes.
answer: Who are they of?

question: Oh, our relatives... the children.
answer: The children! May I see?

question: Of course.
answer: The Children. Where are your children

question: Oh, they're gone for the day... with friends.
answer: Friends. Ah yes, friends! How nice.

question: Here.
answer: Oh... why Mr. Merrick she's beautiful.

question: She has the face of an angel... She was an angel. She was so kind... so kind to me. It's not her fault, for in the fourth month of her maternal condition she was knocked down by an elephant. I'm sure I must have been a great disappointment to her.
answer: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. No. No son as loving as you are could ever be a disappointment.

question: Good morning, Mr. Merrick.
answer: Good morning.

question: What is this that you're doing? What is it? What? Oh! I see! It's St. Phillips. Oh, of course. Why... why that's very good, I mean you've gotten the windows and arches just right.
answer: Yes.

question: But it's so good, I mean... it's so very good.
answer: Thank you... very much.

question: Where did you get this box? The hallway? Oh, the wastecan!
answer: I meant no harm, it was the only place where I could find cardboard. I thought it has been thrown away.

question: It's alright, it was thrown away. No one wants it. It's just that it's a little dirty, that's all. What's this?
answer: The main spire.

question: The... oh, the spire! How silly of me, it's as plain as day... Mr. Merrick, where did you learn to do this?
answer: ...I learned a long time ago.

question: Oh, but how will you finish it? You haven't any more cardboard.
answer: I'll have to find some more.

question: Good day, Mr. Merrick.
answer: Good day...!

question: I've brought you some things. I hope you'll like, Mr. Merrick. I hope you don't think it too forward.
answer: Oh, no.

question: I knew you'd understand. Here. I want you to know that I don't go about giving my pictures to just anyone.
answer: Oh, no. I would never think it! It's so beautiful. You are so... I'll give it a place of honor, here, next to my mother.

question: She's very pretty, your mother.
answer: Yes. Mr. Treves says that you are in the theatre. Do you live there?

question: Oh no, Mr. Merrick. I just work there.
answer: Well, even to work there would be wonderful. Is it beautiful?

question: You've never been?
answer: Alas, no.

question: Well you must go. It is one of the most beautiful places on earth. Of course, I'm rather partial.
answer: Tell me about it, please!

question: It's very difficult to put into a nutshell, but I should say the theater is the shrine of the imagination, where one may suspend disbelief and travel anywhere in the world, to any time you desire. You may look over the shoulders of kings, unobserved, battle with ruthless tyrants, and marry the beautiful princess, all in the space of a few hours. Onstage you may be whoever you wish to be, do anything you please, and always, always live happily ever after. The theatre is all the brightest and best things of the world, Mr. Merrick. It is lights and music, gaiety and joy. It's... well, it's romance.
answer: Romance!

question: That's one thing the theatre has in great store. which reminds me. I have something else for you... Have you read it?
answer: No, but I certainly shall. Romeo and Juliet. I know of this... "If I profane with my unworthiest hand, This holy shrine, the gentle fine is this

question: Good pilgrim, you do wrong your hand too much, Which mannerly devotion shows in this; For saints have hands that pilgrims hands do touch, And palm to palm is holy palmer's kiss.
answer: Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?

question: Ay, pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer.
answer: O, then, dear saint, let lips do what hands do. They pray, grant thou, lest faith turn to despair.

question: Why, Mr. Merrick, you're not an Elephant Man at all...
answer: Oh no?

question: Watery headed bunch.
answer: I regret that I must leave you here, m' Lord, m' Lady. Thank you so much for coming. It was an act of the greatest charity. Incredible, isn't it? Well, I think John has had enough visitors for one day, Mothershead. I've got a lecture at the college, I'll be back this evening.

question: Excuse me, sir. I'd like to have a word with you.
answer: Oh?... Well, quickly please, Mothershead, I'm overdue.

question: I can't understand why you let those people go in there, sir.
answer: Now Mothershead, you have to understand that this is very good for John. He relishes contact with people outside the hospital...

question: But you saw them, sir. They couldn't hide their disgust. They don't care anything for John, they're just trying to impress their friends.
answer: Aren't you being just a little harsh, Mothershead? You yourself hardly treated John with much loving kindness when he first arrived.

question: I bathed him, didn't I? I fed him and cleaned up after him! If loving kindness can be called care and practical concern, then yes, I did treat him with loving kindness, and I'm not ashamed to say it.
answer: You're right, Mothershead, please forgive me... Of course, I appreciate everything you've done for John, and I'm glad that you are concerned about his welfare. But, I'm the physician in charge and I must do what I think best. I'm also very late, so please forgive me.

question: When will the stream be aweary of flowing under my eye? When will the wind be aweary of blowing over the sky? When will the clouds be aweary of fleeting? When will the heart be aweary of beating, and nature die?
answer: Never, oh! Never, nothing will die. the stream flows the wind blows the heart beats Nothing will die.

question: Mr. Treves, there is something I've been meaning to ask you for some time...
answer: Yes, John?

question: ...Can you cure me?
answer: No John, I can't. I can care for you, but I can't cure you.

question: I thought as much.
answer: John...?

question: Come in.
answer: Are you looking for me, Sister?

question: The cathedral is coming along nicely.
answer: Yes, soon I will start the main spire, but I must finish these columns first, How kind of her!

question: How blind of me. Is there anything else, John, anything at all that I could get for you?
answer: Oh no! There is nothing! I have everything, you have given me everything I could possibly want. I am happy every hour of the day. I only wish there was something I could give to you.

question: Please John, it would give me so much pleasure to give you something. Something just for yourself. Isn't there something you would like to have? You want a dressing bag, John?
answer: You don't think it's too gaudy, do you?

question: Mr. Treves, some more books arrived for Mr. Merrick.
answer: Thank you, Mothershead. Have a porter put them in my office.

question: Yes sir. What's that?
answer: A dressing bag.

question: Very smart indeed.
answer: Yes. John wants it.

question: A dressing bag?
answer: You don't think it's too gaudy, do you.

question: Well...
answer: John thinks it's very dashing. Something no gentleman should be without. I'm inclined to agree.

question: You stay with me.
answer: Dinner will be served, shortly, dear. More romances for John?

question: Hmmm?
answer: ...Freddie! What's the matter? You've been like this all evening.

question: Oh... I've just been thinking about something that man Bytes said.
answer: Oh, Freddie. What could that wretched vampire say to upset you?

question: That I am very little different from him.
answer: Oh that's absurd, Frederick. No, no Frederick, that's all wrong! John is happier and more fulfilled now than he has ever been in his entire life. And, that is completely due to you.

question: But why did I do it? What was this all for? So John Merrick could live out his last days in peace and comfort? Or so I could become famous?
answer: Frederick, just what is it that you are saying?

question: ...Am I a good man or am I a bad man?
answer: Oh Frederick. You're a good man. A very good man.

question: Mr. Chairman! I was under the distinct impression that we had concluded discussion of this disagreeable matter. Had we not ascertained that an Elephant Man is not acceptable as a patient? Have we not, very generously, allowed the creature to use two of our rooms until such time as he could be properly disposed of? Have we not...
answer: I must be more careful!

question: Which brings to mind my next point. The rules, gentlemen, the rules. In a society such as ours, it is of paramount importance that we not stray from the established order. Has that order not already been fearfully strained by allowing this... this... sideshow exhibit to take up residence, however temporary, in two very useful rooms, the purpose of which would be far better served in accommodating treatable patients, patients to whom this hospital was originally dedicated? I believe we have a duty...
answer: ...Ladybug, ladybug, fly away home... it's cloudy out, I know, but remember; behind the clouds there is always the sun.

question: ...my... home?
answer: Yes, John.

question: You did this for me?
answer: Yes.

question: Please... please thank the governing committee for me. I will do my utmost to merit their kindness. My home.
answer: There is one more thing, John. Here. Is it the one you wanted?

question: Oh, Mr. Treves. Mr. Treves.
answer: Are you sure? Because I can take it back.

question: You're on mate. Alright, alright, that's enough for this performance. Hang on, hang on, there's always tomorrow night. Not to worry.
answer: Room for one more?

question: At the right price... There's room.
answer: Well, let's be off then.

question: Curtain time!!! No, no! You look lovely. Don't change a thing, darling. You look like the bleedin' Prince of Wales. My friends... The Elephant Man!
answer: Perhaps the ladies would like a closer look?

question: A prince needs a harem! Mind his head... You'll kill him. Quiet down. Quiet down. You'll have the whole place down on us.
answer: Bring him out then, so's we all can see him.

question: Everyone outside!!! Here now... Here now... He's had enough... show's over! Meet you at the Peacock. He's had 'is fill for one night. I did real well tonight. Here... buy yourself a sweet.
answer: My treasure... Aren't you glad to see me?

question: My treasure... Aren't you glad to see me?
answer: Bytes!

question: Get into your cloak... ...now, your hood... do it!
answer: ...Alright.

question: WHERE IS HE? WHERE IS MR. MERRICK?
answer: I... I don't know what you mean, Sir.

question: Don't lie to me. I know all about it. You were SEEN. Where did you take him?
answer: Take him? Now wait... I didn't take him anywhere. We were just having some fun. We didn't hurt him... just having a laugh, that's all.

question: HE'S GONE!
answer: When I left him, he was in his bed, safe and sound.

question: YOU BASTARD! You tortured him. YOU TORTURED HIM, you bastard. WHERE is HE?
answer: YOU'RE NOT LISTENING TO ME! I ain't done nothing wrong. People pay to see your monster, Mr. Treves. I just take the money.

question: YOU'RE THE MONSTER! YOU'RE THE FREAK! GET OUT! YOU'RE FINISHED!
answer: Have a care, Mr. Treves. I ain't afraid of you! You and your bleedin' Elephant Man! I'm glad what I did! And you can't do nothing! Only Mothershead can sack me.

question: Eat, my treasure, I want you healthy. I'm beginning to feel your weight. ...The result is plain to see. Ladies and Gentlemen... THE TERRIBLE ELEPHANT MAN! Turn around! Dance! Dance! Eat, my treasure. Eat. I said eat! Eat, damn you. EAT! EAT! I said EAT!! The result is plain to see. Ladies and gentlemen... THE TERRIBLE ELEPHANT Turn around! Dance! Up! Up! Give the call of the elephant! Louder! Get up you miserable bastard! I SAID, GET UP! I'm beatin' a dead horse. Another bleedin' heart! You sly bastard. You're doing this to spite me, aren't you!
answer: Aw, Bytes, he's sick.

question: He's doing it to spite me, I tell you, and it's got to stop!
answer: He's sick, Bytes. He's going to die.

question: If he does it's his own fault! But I'm not burying that swollen bag of flesh.
answer: What are you going to do?

question: I'll show you! I'll show you!
answer: Don't!

question: Shut up!
answer: Bytes, please...

question: Bytes! Bytes, please!! NO! I AM NOT AN ELEPHANT! I AM NOT AN ANIMAL!! I AM A HUMAN BEING! I... AM... A MAN! I AM A MAN!!
answer: You alright?

question: y-y-yes--
answer: Want to come out?

question: You're English.
answer: Of course! You want out?

question: Yes.
answer: Won't be a moment. We've decided... You've got to get away from here...

question: Thank you, my friends.
answer: I'll go in with you, you'll need a ticket. I'm just going to help my friend on board. This'll do. I'm sorry I could only get you a third class ticket, but it's all we had.

question: Oh no, my friend...
answer: Say hello to London for me. I miss her.

question: Oh, yes.
answer: You know, I saw you once there, in London. You're a great attraction. Luck, my friend, luck. Who needs it more than we?

question: It's all arranged. I'll send over some evening gowns for the sisters that you select to accompany Mr. Merrick. You'll be using the Royal entrance and Princess Alexandra herself will be there to welcome him to her private box.
answer: I'm very grateful to you, Mrs. Kendal. This is just the thing to help him forget his ordeal. John will be very excited.

question: Well it is a miracle he ever got back. And, I'm sure, Mr. Treves, under your expert care, he'll have many happy years ahead.
answer: I fear not, Mrs. Kendal. Even in the short time he was gone the size of his head has increased rapidly... as is his pain.

question: How awful for John.
answer: And yet, not once have any of us heard him complain.

question: Is he... dying then?
answer: Yes. There is nothing more frustrating, nothing that makes a physician feel more useless, than standing by watching his patient deteriorate. And when that patient is a friend, no... no, there's absolutely nothing I can do.

question: Well, it's all quite... I've never heard... It's quite...
answer: Yes.
